title: Before reading the Bhagavad Gita, which book should I read first? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mahabharata (Back Story, Context) & Srimad Bhagavatam Light a lamp and listen with your whole being to the Moola Parayanam (Root Recitation) before beginning…   In Audio format: http://mantratrance.com/audios/srimad-bhagavatam All chapters are rendered in Sanskrit and perfectly recited. Merely listening will purify the senses. Understanding will transform your life. For English, I recommend: The Concise Srimad Bhagavatam: Venkatesananda, Swami: 9780791401491: Amazon.com: Books Also, the kindle version of the Mahabharata for the backstory and context of the Gita: Amazon.com: Pictorial Mahabharata eBook: Raghaveshananda , Swami: Kindle Store Once you are hooked, I suggest learning Sanskrit and get the original “as it is” unembellished by translational errors:   Reading of the Bhagavatam fulfills the critiera that you read Bhagavad Gita with bhakti. The Bhagavatam instills bhakti which will orient you with the right attitude when approaching the Bhagavad Gita, for maximum benefit. “But, those who carp and cavil at My teaching and do not practice it, consider them as ignorant of all knowledge, senseless, and lost.” ~ Sri Krishna paramatma

If you are new to Vedic concepts then you might like to read Mahabharata. Bhagavad Gita is set within the greater history of Mahabharat which is the setting for the jewel that is Bhagavad Gita. It’s a big book and a great story, but there are editions by Puranprajna dasa and Krishna Dharma dasa that present it as prose and not simply a translation of the individual texts. If you are interested simply in the philosophy of Bhagavad Gita then it would be good to chose a small book by Srila Prabhupada that will be based on the core elements of Bhagavad Gita. Any Iskcon temple you contact will have copies and be able to recommend one. You can read the Bhagwad Gita directly. I have read Gita directly and got complete benefit. The best version of Gita is “Bhagwad Gita As It Is” by Srila Prabhupada and this is the one I read. If you need to read any book before this you can read a bunch of books by the same author. Especially Science of Self Realization Path of Perfection Bhagwad Gita is not just a religious book but more like a manual for life. So you can read the book directly without any introduction.

Before reading Bhagavad Gita, it’s highly recommended to understand Vedas. Vedas are made up of smaller groups of text known as Upanishads. Any one Upanishad from each of the Veda sounds good. More than that is also fine. The reason is that, the deeper meaning of Bhagavad Gita can be understood and felt only with some knowledge of Vedas. Of course, translations and good explanatory books are available, but this path helps to understand the meaning truly and also there will be self realisation.

I would suggest reading a synopsis of the Mahabharata first just to get a little background. It is not necessary to read the whole Mahabharata to understand the Bhagavad Geeta. Properly understanding it, however is a lifelong journey. One can read it over and over again and gain new insights every time. Reading the Upanishads and the going back and reading the Geeta will always shed new light on the teachings. I also suggest Swami Dayanand Saraswati’s “Teachings of the Bhagavad Geeta” as a tool to better understand the contents.

Perhaps you should read Srimad Bhagavatam first, before proceeding to The Bhagavad-Gita. And few Puranas or stories, to get into the bhava for reading the Gita. Bhagavad-Gita is a contemplative subject and it is good to be emotionally, mentally prepared to get into that state.

I believe that Rama sets characteristics of a king & kingdom. Krishna tells us the characteristics of a man who lives in Ramrajya.. an individual unit of Ramrajya! Character of Rama required more explanation which has been given by Krishna in Geeta. So, in my opinion before Geeta, Ramayan of Balmiki & Ramcharitmanas of Tulsi must be read & grasped. To understand situations of now days Mahabharat also may be read.

You should read Mahabratha first. It will provide some good background story to the messages stated in Bhavagad Gita. Because many of the messages in the Gita actually reflects the actions done by the characters (including Sri Krishna) in the Mahabratha Epic as well.
i will suggest to read Bhagavad Gita itself., its not a book to read once and keep aside and there are no pre requisites for it.
